notes:
1. Concept

The triple point of a substance is the unique combination of temperature and pressure at which its solid, liquid, and gaseous phases can coexist in thermodynamic equilibrium.

2. Phase Diagram

On a pressure-temperature (P-T) phase diagram, the triple point is the single point where the three phase boundary lines meet:

  • The melting/freezing curve (solid-liquid boundary)
  • The vaporization/condensation curve (liquid-gas boundary)
  • The sublimation/deposition curve (solid-gas boundary)

3. Example: Water

The triple point of water is used to define the Kelvin, the SI base unit of thermodynamic temperature. It occurs at a temperature of 273.16 K (0.01 °C) and a vapor pressure of 611.66 pascals (approx. 0.006 atm). At this specific point, you can have ice, liquid water, and water vapor all existing together in a stable state.

solvedExamples.question: The triple point of a substance is the point on a P-T phase diagram where:

options.text: The liquid and gas phases become indistinguishable.
Only the solid phase can exist.
The solid, liquid, and gas phases coexist in equilibrium.
The substance is in a supercritical state.

solvedExamples.explanation: By definition, the triple point is the unique temperature and pressure at which all three phases—solid, liquid, and gas—can exist simultaneously in a stable equilibrium.
